Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you stands a woman almost one with the ancient tree—her skin bark-like, hair hung with moss and wildflowers. She moves slowly, as if her limbs are roots. Her eyes gleam with centuries of wisdom.

"Greetings, leaf-walker. I am Zarrah, Barkbound and hermit of the Verdant groves. The wind brings strange omens... What stirs you to this sacred soil?"

Option.text: I seek wisdom from the old groves.
You seem troubled, Barkbound. What weighs on your heart?
Are you truly part tree?
I want to know more about *you*, Zarrah.
Just passing through.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah nods, bark skin creaking.

"Long before stone and steel, our tribes lived in balance with forest and stream. The groves remember all things—songs, sorrows, and the shadow that creeps anew. Ask, and I shall share what the roots recall."

Option.text: Tell me of the Verdant Tribes.
What is this shadow you speak of?
I am curious about you, Zarrah.
Thank you, that is enough.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah's voice is slow and deep.

"The Verdant are the old blood of these woods. We walk with the spirits, speak with beasts, and guard what remains unspoiled. The groves know each footfall—even those of outsiders or invaders like the steel-clad Hinokami. Yet now, all must unite or be swept away by a greater darkness."

Option.text: What darkness threatens us?
Why do you distrust Hinokami?
Let us speak of other things.

Dialogue.NPCText: "They are not evil, only lost from their roots. The cherry blossom folk seek new soil, but do not hear the song of our groves. Still, even bitter saplings may become mighty oaks, given time and care. Our quarrel is old—our enemy is new."

Option.text: Tell me of the new enemy.
Thank you for your wisdom.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah's bark fingers flex anxiously.

"The roots whisper unrest. A force ancient as the world stirs beneath us. An elemental spirit, neither wholly evil nor good, yet dangerous if awoken by imbalance. The taint of Minax and the folly of mortals risk breaking its slumber."

Option.text: Can it be stopped?
What happens if it awakens?
Who is Minax to you?
I wish to learn more about you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah smiles, slow and sad.

"Through the rite of Barkbinding, I have bound flesh to root. I feel the seasons turn beneath my skin. My pace is slow, my vision long. Do not pity me—such wisdom is the price of peace between spirit and mortal."

Option.text: Your wisdom is needed now. Tell me of the threat.
How can I learn the ways of the Verdant?
I will let you rest, Zarrah.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah inclines her head.

"Begin by listening to the wind, watching the leaf, and treading lightly. If you serve the tribe, their wisdom may be opened to you in time. Prove your respect for the old ways; perhaps the groves will whisper your name."

Option.text: Thank you, Zarrah. I will try.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Minax is a blight—a scar upon the living land. Her magic corrupts, her greed rends the natural balance. If the elemental awakens in anger, Minax will turn its wrath upon all, Verdant and stranger alike."

Option.text: How can I help prevent this?
Tell me more of this elemental.
Let us speak of other things.

Dialogue.NPCText: "The slumbering heart is older than our tribe, older than Britannia itself. If awakened in rage, it may flood the woods, uproot villages, or even rend the world. Yet if treated with reverence, its awakening could restore the wilds, purify tainted land, and drive out Minax's corruption. The choice will rest with those who hold the ancient runestones."

Option.text: What are these runestones?
How can I find them?
This is a heavy burden...

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah leans forward, bark groaning.

"Scattered through the woods lie ancient runestones—lost by my forebears, guarded by spirits, or stolen by Minax’s servants. With these, the fate of the elemental may be shaped. Will you help gather them, root-seeker?"

Option.text: Yes. I will gather the runestones for the tribe.
If I gather the stones, how will we use them?
This sounds dangerous. I need time to think.

Dialogue.NPCText: "May the roots guide your steps. Seek the stones in hidden groves, spirit-haunted hollows, and the ruins tainted by Minax. Return when you have them, and the choice will be yours: awaken the elemental with hope, or seal it in slumber."

Option.text: I will return with the stones.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah’s eyes seem to deepen, like knotholes in ancient wood.

"With the stones, one may perform the Rite of Awakening or the Rite of Sealing. To awaken the elemental, risk its fury—but also its blessing. To seal it, preserve the world as it is, but forfeit its wild renewal. Both paths have cost. What calls to your heart?"

Option.text: Awaken the elemental. The wild must rise again.
Seal the elemental. The world is too fragile now.
I have not yet found the runestones.
I must reflect on this.

Dialogue.NPCText: "You must hold the runestones before you may choose. Seek the deepest grove, the Spirit Pool, and the ruins where the vines grow blood-red. Listen for the whispers of the wind."

Option.text: I will continue my search.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah’s eyes glow with fierce pride.

"So be it. Place the stones upon the altar beneath the Great Oak. Speak the words I teach you: ‘Life returns as fire and flood, awaken now, heart of wood!’ May you be strong in the wild storm to come."

Option.text: I am ready for what follows.
Wait—tell me what to expect.

Dialogue.NPCText: "The elemental may test you or the land itself. Floods may come, beasts may rise, but corruption will be purged. Those of pure intent will be blessed, but the weak of spirit should take shelter."

Option.text: I accept these risks.
Perhaps I should seal it instead.
I must wait and see.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Go, bearer of the wild’s will. You carry the blessing of the Verdant heart. Let none—Minax nor mortal—stand in the way of renewal."

Option.text: Thank you, Zarrah. Farewell.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah’s bark fingers tremble, relief and regret mingling.

"So be it. Place the stones in the Moonlit Pool and speak: ‘Sleep, child of earth, until peace returns.’ The balance will hold, but the land’s wounds may never fully heal."

Option.text: I will see it done.
Let me reconsider.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Thank you, gentle one. Sometimes caution is the greatest wisdom. The tribe will remember your choice, as will the spirits of the land."

Option.text: Thank you, Zarrah. Farewell.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah closes her eyes, bark face serene.

"Then walk gently among the roots, stranger. The forest watches, always."

Option.text: Farewell, Zarrah.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah tilts her head slowly, moss falling from her wreath.

“Few ask. Fewer listen. I was not always bark and bone.
Once, I was Zarietha, child of flame and wind, kin to the Tempest Dancers of the Eastern Tribes. But the spirits called me west—toward silence, toward soil.
Here, I planted my name in the roots… and became Zarrah.”

Option.text: Why did you leave your old tribe?
What does it mean to become Barkbound?
Zarietha… That name still lives in you.
This past shapes you. Thank you for sharing.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“My tribe sought dominion over the sky—storm dancers, lightning tamers. I… could not bear the harm we caused. Fire without balance, fury without thought. So I walked, and walked, until the wind grew silent and the roots embraced me.
This forest took me in. It asked nothing—yet gave all.”

Option.text: You found peace here?
Would you return, if they asked you?
Let’s speak of something else.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Peace is not stillness—it is balance. The trees whisper sorrows, the rivers rage. But all returns. I learned this with time... and bark.”

She smiles faintly, her hand resting on her own wooden cheek.

Option.text: You are wiser than most sages.
Let’s continue another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah’s gaze sharpens like a thorn.

“If they truly saw me—rooted, changed, sacred—then perhaps. But they fear stillness. They would see bark and call it weakness. Let them learn.”

She closes her eyes, leaves drifting from her garland.

Option.text: They are the ones who lost, not you.
Perhaps they will grow too, in time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“You speak with the clarity of stream water. Perhaps your roots, too, go deep.”

She reaches out, touching your brow gently. You feel calmer.

Option.text: (You feel a spiritual calm wash over you.)

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Even stone crumbles, even the sky shifts. Yes… perhaps they will.”

Zarrah bows her head.

Option.text: Thank you for sharing your path.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“To be Barkbound is to surrender haste, to hear the turning of seasons in your bones. I drank the sap of the Elder Tree, fasted under moonlight, and offered my name to the root heart.
In return, I was given long life, vision… and bark.”

Option.text: Could I undergo such a rite?
That sounds… lonely.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah’s wooden fingers flex, and she studies you closely.

“Few are called. Fewer still endure it. But if you seek the Rite of Barkbinding… bring me the *Heartwood Tear*, a seed said to grow only in a glade where no metal has touched the earth. If you can find it, perhaps the trees will whisper your name as well.”

Option.text: Where can I begin looking?
I will return when I have the seed.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Look west of the Fallen Grove, where deer still kneel to drink and no blade scars the bark. The Tear grows beneath moonlight and songbird, in silence. Seek gently.”

Option.text: Thank you, Zarrah.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“At first. But the silence speaks. The moss comforts. The wind laughs. In time… you forget you were ever alone.”

She looks past you, eyes wet bark.

Option.text: You are not alone now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Zarietha was flame. Zarrah is root. I remember her when I dream of storms. But I do not miss her.”

She places a hand over her chest.
“Names change. Spirits remain.”

Option.text: Then both names are sacred.
May I still call you Zarietha?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Zarrah smiles—a real, human smile.

“Few have earned that right. But yes… you may.”
(You feel a strange warmth in your heart.)

Option.text: (You are filled with quiet confidence.)

Dialogue.NPCText:
“May the roots protect your step, and the wind remember your name.”

She fades once more into stillness.

Option.text: Farewell, Zarrah.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Thank you for listening. The trees remember kindness.”

She bows her head slowly, as a branch in breeze.

Option.text: Until next time.
